The most effective treatment for this condition is neostigmine therapy, which increases colonic motility. Permanent interventions, such as percutaneous cecostomy or laparotomy, are reserved for cases in which conservative measures fail or the patient develops complications. Colonoscopy is contraindicated in this situation due to the risk of colonic perforation.

Neostigmine therapy, a cholinesterase inhibitor, can be used to treat acute colonic pseudo-obstruction (Ogilvie syndrome) which is characterized by colonic distention without mechanical obstruction. Surgery is typically reserved for cases of colonic perforation, ischemia or evident mechanical obstruction. Percutaneous cecostomy is an option for selected cases but is not the first-line therapy. Colonoscopy may be helpful for diagnosis but not for treatment.
